December 18, 1988: Fiction
THE SANDS OF TIME, by Sidney Sheldon. (Morrow, $19.95.) Four nuns become
pawns in a struggle between the Spanish Army and Basque separatists.
THE CARDINAL OF THE KREMLIN, by Tom Clancy. (Putnam, $19.95.) The
C.I.A.'s Jack Ryan races to the rescue of America's highest-ranking secret agent
in the Soviet Union.
THE POLAR EXPRESS, written and illustrated by Chris Van Allsburg. (Houghton
Mifflin, $16.95.) A small boy's Christmas Eve train ride to the North Pole and the
magical events that follow.
THE QUEEN OF THE DAMNED, by Anne Rice. (Knopf, $18.95.) Continuing the
chronicle of 6,000 years of vampirism begun in ''Interview With the Vampire'' and
''The Vampire Lestat.''
DEAR MILI, by Wilhelm Grimm. (di Capua/Farrar, Straus & Giroux, $16.95.) A
recently discovered tale by the 19th-century folklorist, illustrated by Maurice
Sendak.
ONE, by Richard Bach. (Silver Arrow/Morrow, $17.95.) A man and his wife find
themselves in a fantasy world where the possibilities of their pasts still exist.
ALASKA, by James A. Michener. (Random House, $22.50.) The history of the
49th state told in fictional form.
MITLA PASS, by Leon Uris. (Doubleday, $19.95.) A writer's struggles with his
heritage and two loves reach a climax during the 1956 Sinai War.
ANYTHING FOR BILLY, by Larry McMurtry. (Simon & Schuster, $18.95.) The
exploits of Billy the Kid, as shared by a dime-novel writer from Philadelphia.
FINAL FLIGHT, by Stephen Coonts. (Doubleday, $18.95.) Colonel Qazi, an
''international terrorist,'' plots to steal American nuclear weapons.
BREATHING LESSONS, by Anne Tyler. (Knopf, $18.95.) The many facets of a
28-year marriage are revealed during a drive to a friend's funeral.
THE SHELL SEEKERS, by Rosamunde Pilcher. (Dunne/St. Martin's, $19.95.) A
woman and a painting tie together three generations of an English family.
DRAGONSDAWN, by Anne McCaffrey. (Del Rey/Ballantine, $18.95.) The
colonists who settle on a paradisiacal planet make plans to keep it from being
destroyed by a strange force.
ZOYA, by Danielle Steel. (Delacorte, $19.95.) One woman's story, from St.
Petersburg during the Russian Revolution to Paris in the 1920's to contemporary
New York.
December 18, 1988
Non-Fiction
GRACIE, by George Burns. (Putnam, $16.95.) The life of the comedian Gracie
Allen, recalled by her widower and show business partner.
ALL I REALLY NEED TO KNOW I LEARNED IN KINDERGARTEN, by Robert
Fulghum. (Villard, $15.95.) Inspirational essays about everyday matters.
CHILD STAR, by Shirley Temple Black. (McGraw-Hill, $19.95.) The autobiography
of the No. 1 film actress of the mid-1930's.
A BRIEF HISTORY OF TIME, by Stephen W. Hawking. (Bantam, $18.95.) A
British scientist's review of efforts to create a unified theory of the universe.
THE LAST LION, by William Manchester. (Little, Brown, $24.95.) The second
volume of a biography of Winston Churchill, covering the years 1932-40.
DON'T BEND OVER IN THE GARDEN, GRANNY, YOU KNOW THEM TATERS
GOT EYES, by Lewis Grizzard. (Villard, $15.95.) Humor with a Southern accent.
SEVEN STORIES OF CHRISTMAS LOVE, by Leo Buscaglia. (Slack, $12.95.)
The advocate of caring and love recalls experiences during holidays past.
CHRISTMAS IN AMERICA, edited by David Cohen. (Collins Publishers, $35.) An
album of pictures taken by 100 photographers.
A BRIGHT SHINING LIE, by Neil Sheehan. (Random House, $24.95.) A biography
of Lieut. Col. John Paul Vann that is also a history of American involvement in
Vietnam.
THE FIRST SALUTE, by Barbara W. Tuchman. (Knopf, $22.95.) A historian's view
of the American Revolution.
GOLDWATER, by Barry M. Goldwater with Jack Casserly. (Doubleday, $21.95.)
The memoirs of the longtime Senator from Arizona and 1964 Republican
Presidential nominee.
CHRONICLE OF THE 20TH CENTURY, edited by Clifton Daniel. (Chronicle
Publications, $49.95.) Profusely illustrated history of the world, month by month,
from 1900 through 1986.
â€˜'WHAT DO YOU CARE WHAT OTHER PEOPLE THINK?'' by Richard P.
Feynman with Ralph Leighton. (Norton, $17.95.) Memoirs of the Nobel Prize-
winning physicist.
TALKING STRAIGHT, by Lee Iacocca with Sonny Kleinfield. (Bantam, $21.95.)
More experiences and opinions of the Chrysler chairman.
THE HOME PLANET, edited by Kevin W. Kelley. (Addison-Wesley, $39.95.) How
